name: Wangari Maathai
summary: Wangari Maathai was a Kenyan environmentalist who founded the Green Belt Movement, planting over 51 million trees across Africa. She won the 2004 Nobel Peace Prize for her contributions to sustainable development, democracy, and peace. She was the first African woman to receive the Nobel Prize and the first woman in East Africa to earn a PhD.
timeline: Earned MS from University of Pittsburgh
First East African woman to earn a PhD (University of Nairobi)
Successfully opposed skyscraper in Uhuru Park

name: Philip Emeagwali
summary: Philip Emeagwali is a Nigerian-born computer scientist who achieved a computing speed of 3.1 billion calculations per second on the Connection Machine in 1989, winning the Gordon Bell Prize. He used a system of 65,536 processors connected in a pattern inspired by the geometry of bees' honeycombs to solve petroleum reservoir modeling problems.
timeline: Won Gordon Bell Prize for parallel computing

name: Thomas Odhiambo
summary: Thomas Odhiambo was a Kenyan entomologist who founded the International Centre of Insect Physiology and Ecology (ICIPE) in Nairobi. He pioneered research on using biological pest control methods in tropical agriculture. His work on crop pest management helped millions of African farmers improve yields while reducing pesticide dependency.
timeline: Developed biological pest control for Africa

name: Calestous Juma
summary: Calestous Juma was a Kenyan-born environmental scientist and professor at Harvard Kennedy School who pioneered the study of innovation and technology in developing countries. He authored the Convention on Biological Diversity and advocated for the use of genetically modified crops to address food insecurity in Africa. His work bridged science, policy, and development.
timeline: Published first major work on genetic resources
Authored UN Convention on Biological Diversity
Founded African Centre for Technology Studies

name: Quarraisha Abdool Karim
summary: Quarraisha Abdool Karim is a South African infectious disease epidemiologist who made landmark contributions to HIV prevention research. She led the CAPRISA 004 trial demonstrating that tenofovir gel could reduce HIV infection in women by 39%. Her research has been pivotal in understanding HIV transmission dynamics and developing prevention strategies for women.
timeline: Contributed to COVID-19 research in South Africa

name: Segenet Kelemu
summary: Segenet Kelemu is an Ethiopian molecular plant pathologist who served as Director General of the International Centre of Insect Physiology and Ecology (ICIPE). She pioneered research on endophytic fungi in tropical grasses and their potential for improving crop resilience. She has been named one of the most influential African women in science.
timeline: Earned PhD from Kansas State University
Appointed leader of tropical forages research
Named L'Oréal-UNESCO Women in Science laureate
Continued insect science for food security research

name: Felix Konotey-Ahulu
summary: Felix Konotey-Ahulu was a Ghanaian physician who was the world's leading authority on sickle cell disease in Africa. He established sickle cell clinics, documented the disease's prevalence across Africa, and advocated for genetic counseling. His work The Sickle Cell Disease Patient remains a landmark reference in hematology.
timeline: Born in Odumase Krobo, Gold Coast (Ghana)
Established sickle cell clinics in Ghana
Published seminal work on sickle cell disease

name: Ameenah Gurib-Fakim
summary: Ameenah Gurib-Fakim is a Mauritian biodiversity scientist and organic chemist who served as President of Mauritius (2015-2018). She has extensively researched the medicinal plants of the Mascarene Islands and authored several books on African flora. She was named one of Foreign Policy's 100 Leading Global Thinkers for her work on biodiversity.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Exeter
Began systematic study of Mascarene medicinal plants
Published comprehensive study of Mauritian flora
Won L'Oréal-UNESCO Women in Science Award

name: Tebello Nyokong
summary: Tebello Nyokong is a South African chemist and professor at Rhodes University who pioneered the use of phthalocyanine dyes in photodynamic therapy (PDT) for cancer treatment and photocatalysis for water purification. She was the first black South African woman to receive a PhD in chemistry and has been named among the most influential scientists in Africa.
timeline: Earned PhD in chemistry from University of Western Ontario
Received L'Oréal-UNESCO Women in Science Award
Pioneer in nanotechnology for cancer treatment

name: Salim Abdool Karim
summary: Salim Abdool Karim is a South African clinical infectious disease epidemiologist who has led groundbreaking HIV prevention and treatment research. He co-founded CAPRISA and served as chair of South Africa's COVID-19 advisory committee. His research on HIV broadly neutralizing antibodies and prevention has shaped global AIDS policy.
timeline: Co-founded CAPRISA (Centre for AIDS Programme of Research)
Advanced HIV broadly neutralizing antibody research
Key role in CAPRISA 004 microbicide trial
Chaired South Africa's COVID-19 Ministerial Advisory Committee

name: Francisca Nneka Okeke
summary: Francisca Nneka Okeke is a Nigerian physicist who became the first female professor of physics at the University of Nigeria. Her research focuses on the dynamic effects of the ionosphere on radio communication and navigation in equatorial Africa. She won the L'Oréal-UNESCO Women in Science Award for Africa in 2013.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Nigeria
Became first female physics professor at University of Nigeria
Won L'Oréal-UNESCO Women in Science Award for Africa

name: Adebayo Olukoshi
summary: Adebayo Olukoshi is a Nigerian political economist who has served as director of the United Nations African Institute for Economic Development and Planning. His research on African development, structural adjustment, and democratic governance has shaped policy across the continent. He has been one of Africa's most influential social scientists.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Leeds
Appointed director of UN African Institute for Economic Development

name: Marcos Pontes
summary: Marcos Pontes is the first Brazilian and South American astronaut to go to space. He flew to the International Space Station aboard Soyuz TMA-8 in 2006, spending 10 days conducting experiments in microgravity. A military pilot and engineer, he later served as Brazil's Minister of Science, Technology, and Innovation.
timeline: Born in Bauru, São Paulo, Brazil
Graduated from Brazilian Air Force Academy
Selected as astronaut by Brazilian Space Agency
Trained at NASA Johnson Space Center
Flew to ISS on Soyuz TMA-8
Became Brazil's Minister of Science and Technology

name: Ana María Cetto
summary: Ana María Cetto is a Mexican theoretical physicist who has made contributions to stochastic quantum mechanics and been a leader in international science policy. She served as deputy director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and has advocated for science education and nuclear disarmament in Latin America.
timeline: Became deputy director general of IAEA
Continued physics and science policy work

name: Marta Lamas
summary: Marta Lamas is a Mexican anthropologist and gender studies scholar who has been one of the most influential feminists and social scientists in Latin America. While primarily a social scientist, her research on gender and public policy has shaped health and science policy across Mexico and the region.

name: Luis Federico Leloir
summary: Luis Federico Leloir was an Argentine biochemist who won the 1970 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for discovering the sugar nucleotides and their role in the biosynthesis of carbohydrates. His research revealed how organisms convert one sugar to another and how glycogen is synthesized. He spent most of his career at the Instituto Campomar in Buenos Aires.
timeline: Graduated from University of Buenos Aires
Worked with Carl and Gerty Cori

name: César Milstein
summary: César Milstein was an Argentine-British biochemist who shared the 1984 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for developing the technique for producing monoclonal antibodies using hybridoma cells. His invention revolutionized diagnostics, treatment, and biological research. Monoclonal antibodies became one of the most important tools in medicine and biotechnology.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Buenos Aires
Joined MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology
Developed monoclonal antibody technique with Georges Köhler
Awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Carlos Chagas
summary: Carlos Chagas was a Brazilian physician who discovered Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis) in 1909, describing the pathogen Trypanosoma cruzi, its insect vector, and the complete disease cycle. He is the only scientist to have described the full epidemiological picture of a new infectious disease — the pathogen, vector, host, symptoms, and treatment — single-handedly.
timeline: Born in Oliveira, Minas Gerais, Brazil
Graduated from medical school in Rio de Janeiro
Studied malaria control in the interior
Described clinical forms of the disease
Became director of Instituto Oswaldo Cruz

name: Mario Molina
summary: Mario Molina was a Mexican chemist who co-discovered that chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) deplete the ozone layer. He shared the 1995 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for this work, which led to the Montreal Protocol banning CFCs. His research literally saved the Earth's ozone layer and prevented millions of skin cancer cases worldwide.
timeline: Published paper on CFC ozone depletion with Rowland
Founded Mario Molina Center in Mexico City

name: Pedro Paulet
summary: Pedro Paulet was a Peruvian scientist who designed and tested a liquid-fueled rocket engine in 1897, potentially before any other experimenter. He designed a spacecraft concept using liquid propulsion decades before modern rocketry. Though his work was not widely recognized internationally, Wernher von Braun acknowledged him as a pioneer of the space age.
timeline: Described torpedo aircraft using rocket propulsion

name: Johanna Döbereiner
summary: Johanna Döbereiner was a Czech-born Brazilian agronomist who discovered that certain bacteria can fix nitrogen in association with tropical grasses and cereals. Her research on biological nitrogen fixation saved Brazil billions of dollars in fertilizer costs and made Brazilian soybean farming globally competitive without synthetic nitrogen.
timeline: Born in Ústí nad Labem, Czechoslovakia
Began nitrogen fixation research at Embrapa
Developed biological nitrogen fixation for soybeans
Brazil saved billions through her BNF technology

name: Manuel Elkin Patarroyo
summary: Manuel Elkin Patarroyo is a Colombian immunologist who developed SPf66, the first synthetic vaccine against malaria. While field trials showed variable efficacy, his work pioneered the synthetic vaccine approach and demonstrated that chemically synthesized peptides could generate immune responses against parasitic diseases. He donated his vaccine patent to the WHO.
timeline: Earned MD from National University of Colombia

name: Nee Win Maung
summary: Nee Win Maung was a Myanmar physician and public health scientist who established HIV/AIDS treatment programs in Myanmar during a period of political isolation. He founded the Myanmar Medical Association's HIV treatment program and trained hundreds of health workers to provide antiretroviral therapy across the country.
timeline: Trained health workers for HIV care

name: Malinee Sripaipan
summary: Malinee Sripaipan is a Thai epidemiologist who has made significant contributions to public health research in Southeast Asia, focusing on HIV prevention, tuberculosis, and tropical disease control. Her research on preventive health interventions has influenced Thai and regional public health policy.
timeline: Led HIV prevention research in Thailand

name: Bambang Hidayat
summary: Bambang Hidayat was Indonesia's most prominent astronomer who directed the Bosscha Observatory and established modern astronomical research in Indonesia. He studied stellar atmospheres and variable stars and represented Indonesia in the International Astronomical Union for decades. He helped develop astronomy education throughout Southeast Asia.
timeline: Researched variable stars and stellar atmospheres
Represented Indonesia in International Astronomical Union

name: Josefina Estola
summary: Josefina Estola was a Filipino virologist who discovered the Manila strain of the avian coronavirus, an important contribution to understanding coronavirus biology. She also researched the Newcastle disease virus and other avian pathogens. Her work at the University of the Philippines College of Veterinary Medicine advanced Philippine virology.
timeline: Discovered Manila strain of avian coronavirus

name: Marian Cleeves Diamond
summary: Marian Diamond was an American neuroscientist who was the first to demonstrate that the brain can change with experience (neuroplasticity). She studied Einstein's brain and found it had more glial cells than average. Her enriched environment studies proved the brain grows and changes throughout life, overturning the dogma that the brain is fixed after development.
timeline: Her UC Berkeley lectures became YouTube phenomenon

name: Ulmas Mirsaidov
summary: Ulmas Mirsaidov was a Tajik physicist who contributed to materials science and semiconductor research in Central Asia. He helped establish physics research infrastructure in Tajikistan and trained a generation of Central Asian physicists. His work on radiation effects on materials was significant for the Soviet space program.
timeline: Led Tajik Academy of Sciences physics department

name: Abylkas Saginov
summary: Abylkas Saginov was a Kazakh mining engineer and geologist who developed innovative methods for mining Kazakhstan's vast mineral deposits. He founded the Karaganda Polytechnic Institute and trained generations of Kazakh mining engineers. His techniques improved the efficiency and safety of coal and mineral extraction in Central Asia.

name: James Watt
summary: James Watt was a Scottish inventor and mechanical engineer whose improvements to the Newcomen steam engine were fundamental to the Industrial Revolution. His separate condenser design dramatically improved steam engine efficiency. He also developed the concept of horsepower and the watt unit of power is named after him. His partnership with Matthew Boulton commercialized the steam engine.
timeline: Became instrument maker at University of Glasgow

name: George Stephenson
summary: George Stephenson was the 'Father of Railways' who built the first public inter-city railway, the Liverpool and Manchester Railway, in 1830. He developed the Rocket locomotive and established the standard gauge (4 feet 8.5 inches) that became the world standard. His engineering achievements launched the railway age that transformed global transportation.
timeline: Appointed engineer of Stockton and Darlington Railway

name: Isambard Kingdom Brunel
summary: Isambard Kingdom Brunel was one of the greatest engineers of the 19th century, designing the Great Western Railway, the Clifton Suspension Bridge, and revolutionary steamships including the SS Great Britain and SS Great Eastern. He pioneered the use of broad gauge railways and drove the development of transatlantic steamship travel.
timeline: Won competition to design Clifton Suspension Bridge
Appointed chief engineer of Great Western Railway
SS Great Western crossed Atlantic in 15 days
SS Great Britain launched (first iron-hulled propeller ship)
SS Great Eastern launched (largest ship for 40 years)

name: Henry Bessemer
summary: Henry Bessemer was an English inventor who developed the Bessemer process in 1856, the first inexpensive method for mass-producing steel from molten pig iron. His invention reduced the cost of steel by over 80% and made steel available in enormous quantities, enabling the construction of railroads, bridges, ships, and skyscrapers that defined the modern world.
timeline: Invented the Bessemer process for steelmaking

name: Thomas Telford
summary: Thomas Telford was a Scottish civil engineer who designed and built roads, bridges, canals, and harbors across Britain. He constructed the Menai Suspension Bridge, the Pontcysyllte Aqueduct, and the Caledonian Canal. Known as the 'Colossus of Roads,' he was the first president of the Institution of Civil Engineers.
timeline: Appointed Surveyor of Public Works for Shropshire
Designed Ellesmere Canal and Pontcysyllte Aqueduct
Became first president of Institution of Civil Engineers

name: Matthew Boulton
summary: Matthew Boulton was a British manufacturer and engineer who partnered with James Watt to commercialize the steam engine. Through their firm Boulton & Watt, they manufactured and installed steam engines across Britain, powering the Industrial Revolution. He also pioneered modern manufacturing methods at his Soho Manufactory in Birmingham.
timeline: First Boulton & Watt steam engine installed
Steam engines powering factories across Britain
Founded Soho Mint for coin production

name: Richard Trevithick
summary: Richard Trevithick was a Cornish inventor who built the world's first full-scale working railway steam locomotive in 1804, carrying passengers and cargo along the Merthyr Tydfil tramroad in Wales. He also developed high-pressure steam engines that were smaller and more powerful than Watt's low-pressure designs, enabling mobile steam power.
timeline: Demonstrated Catch Me Who Can in London
Went to South America for mining work

name: Abraham Darby I
summary: Abraham Darby I was an English ironmaster who pioneered the smelting of iron using coke (from coal) instead of charcoal in 1709. This innovation was fundamental to the Industrial Revolution, as it made iron production cheaper and freed it from dependence on diminishing forests. His Coalbrookdale ironworks became the cradle of the Industrial Revolution.
timeline: First successful coke smelting of iron

name: Carl Benz
summary: Carl Benz was a German engineer who invented the first practical automobile powered by an internal combustion engine. His Benz Patent-Motorwagen of 1886 is considered the first true automobile. He founded Benz & Cie., which later merged with Daimler to form Mercedes-Benz. His wife Bertha's famous long-distance drive proved the car's practicality.
timeline: Founded first company with August Ritter
Produced Benz Velo, first affordable car

name: Gottlieb Daimler
summary: Gottlieb Daimler was a German engineer who independently developed a high-speed internal combustion engine and one of the first motorcycles. With Wilhelm Maybach, he created the first four-wheeled automobile in 1889 and founded Daimler-Motoren-Gesellschaft. His engines powered boats, cars, and the first airships. His company later became Mercedes-Benz.
timeline: Left Deutz, set up workshop with Maybach

name: Rudolf Diesel
summary: Rudolf Diesel was a German inventor who developed the diesel engine, which uses compression ignition instead of a spark plug. Patented in 1893 and demonstrated in 1897, the diesel engine was more efficient than existing engines. It became the dominant power source for trucks, ships, trains, and power generation worldwide. He disappeared mysteriously from a ship.
timeline: Graduated from Technical University of Munich
First successful diesel engine test in Augsburg
Demonstrated diesel engine running on peanut oil
Disappeared from SS Dresden in English Channel

name: Werner von Siemens
summary: Werner von Siemens was a German inventor and industrialist who built the first electric railway, the first electric elevator, and developed the electric dynamo. He founded Siemens AG, which became one of the world's largest electrical engineering companies. His inventions in telegraphy, electrical power, and transportation transformed modern infrastructure.
timeline: Built first electric railway in Berlin

name: Andrew Carnegie
summary: Andrew Carnegie was a Scottish-American industrialist who led the expansion of the American steel industry in the late 19th century. His Carnegie Steel Company became the largest steel producer in the world, using the Bessemer process and vertical integration. He later became one of history's greatest philanthropists, funding libraries, universities, and research institutions.
timeline: Carnegie Steel became largest in the world
Sold Carnegie Steel to J.P. Morgan for $480 million

name: Eli Whitney
summary: Eli Whitney was an American inventor who created the cotton gin in 1793, revolutionizing cotton production in the American South. He also pioneered the concept of interchangeable parts in manufacturing, which he demonstrated in his musket factory. His manufacturing innovations were foundational to the American System of manufacturing and mass production.

name: Samuel Morse
summary: Samuel Morse was an American inventor and painter who developed the electric telegraph and Morse code, revolutionizing long-distance communication. His first telegraph message, 'What hath God wrought,' was sent from Washington to Baltimore in 1844. His system became the standard for global telecommunications for over a century.
timeline: Conceived electric telegraph on ship voyage
Received $30,000 from Congress for telegraph line
Sent first telegraph message: 'What hath God wrought'

name: Cyrus McCormick
summary: Cyrus McCormick was an American inventor who developed the mechanical reaper in 1831, revolutionizing grain harvesting and American agriculture. His reaper replaced manual labor with machine harvesting, enabling the Great Plains to become the world's breadbasket. He founded McCormick Harvesting Machine Company, later International Harvester.
timeline: Moved to Chicago, built reaper factory
Won gold medal at Great Exhibition in London
Factory destroyed in Great Chicago Fire, rebuilt

name: Charles Babbage
summary: Charles Babbage was an English mathematician and inventor who conceived the first automatic mechanical computer, the Difference Engine, and designed the more advanced Analytical Engine. The Analytical Engine contained concepts fundamental to modern computers including memory, processing, and programming. He is considered the 'Father of the Computer.'
timeline: Ada Lovelace wrote first algorithm for Analytical Engine
Completed designs for Difference Engine No. 2

name: Joseph Whitworth
summary: Joseph Whitworth was an English engineer who standardized screw threads and developed precision measurement tools that enabled the interchangeable parts manufacturing revolution. His Whitworth thread standard became the first national screw thread standard, and his measuring instruments could detect differences of one millionth of an inch.
timeline: Founded own engineering workshop in Manchester
Displayed precision tools at Great Exhibition
Whitworth thread adopted as British Standard
Developed Whitworth rifle with hexagonal bore

name: Marc Isambard Brunel
summary: Marc Isambard Brunel was a French-born British engineer who designed the Thames Tunnel, the first tunnel successfully constructed underneath a navigable river. He invented the tunneling shield, a revolutionary technique still used in modern tunnel construction. He also designed mass-production machinery for the Royal Navy's block-making at Portsmouth.
timeline: Invented block-making machinery for Royal Navy

name: John Smeaton
summary: John Smeaton was an English civil engineer considered the first person to call himself a 'civil engineer.' He rebuilt the Eddystone Lighthouse using hydraulic lime concrete, a breakthrough that made durable marine structures possible. He also improved the efficiency of waterwheels and windmills through systematic experiments, pioneering the use of scientific methods in engineering.
timeline: Founded the Society of Civil Engineers (Smeatonian Society)

name: Nikola Tesla
summary: Nikola Tesla was a Serbian-American inventor who developed the alternating current (AC) electrical system that powers the modern world. He invented the Tesla coil, AC induction motor, polyphase power systems, and made pioneering contributions to radio, X-rays, and wireless energy transmission. His rivalry with Thomas Edison is legendary, and he held over 300 patents.
timeline: Born in Smiljan, Austrian Empire (modern Croatia)
Filed patents for AC induction motor
Demonstrated AC power at Chicago World's Fair
Conducted high-voltage experiments in Colorado Springs

name: Robert Stephenson
summary: Robert Stephenson was a British civil engineer, son of George Stephenson, who designed many of the most important railway bridges and locomotives of the early railway age. He built the Britannia Bridge, the High Level Bridge, and designed the Rocket locomotive. He was considered the greatest engineer of the Victorian era.
timeline: Became managing director of Robert Stephenson and Company
Appointed chief engineer of London and Birmingham Railway
Designed Britannia Bridge over Menai Strait
Built High Level Bridge in Newcastle

name: Joseph Bramah
summary: Joseph Bramah was an English inventor and locksmith who developed the hydraulic press (Bramah press), an unpickable lock, a beer engine for pubs, and a flushing toilet design. His hydraulic press, based on Pascal's principle, became essential for industrial metalworking. He also trained Henry Maudslay, who became the father of machine tool technology.
timeline: Trained Henry Maudslay in his workshop

name: Henry Maudslay
summary: Henry Maudslay was an English engineer considered the father of machine tool technology. He developed the first industrially practical screw-cutting lathe, which enabled the precision manufacturing of screws, nuts, and bolts. His workshop trained many of the greatest engineers of the Industrial Revolution, including Joseph Whitworth and James Nasmyth.

name: James Nasmyth
summary: James Nasmyth was a Scottish engineer who invented the steam hammer in 1839, a critical tool for forging large iron and steel components. The steam hammer enabled the manufacturing of large crankshafts and other heavy components for steamships and railways. He also produced detailed drawings of the lunar surface using telescopic observations.
timeline: Published 'The Moon' with detailed lunar illustrations

name: Thomas Newcomen
summary: Thomas Newcomen was an English inventor who created the atmospheric steam engine in 1712, the first practical engine for pumping water out of mines. His Newcomen engine was the predecessor to Watt's improved steam engine and powered mining operations for over 50 years. It was the first practical application of steam power and launched the age of steam.
timeline: Partnered with Thomas Savery on steam pump
Built first successful atmospheric steam engine at Dudley Castle mine
Engines adopted by coal mines across England

name: Alfred Krupp
summary: Alfred Krupp was a German industrialist who transformed his father's small steel foundry into the largest industrial enterprise in Europe. He pioneered the production of cast steel railroad wheels and artillery, and his company became the main arms supplier of the Prussian military. He developed company towns and welfare programs for his workers.
timeline: Took over family steel foundry at age 14
Displayed steel cannon at Great Exhibition, London
Supplied Prussian army in Franco-Prussian War

name: Henry Ford
summary: Henry Ford was an American industrialist who revolutionized manufacturing with the moving assembly line, making automobiles affordable for the middle class. His Model T (1908) democratized car ownership and his $5 workday doubled workers' wages. Ford Motor Company became one of the largest companies in the world and transformed American society.
timeline: Introduced moving assembly line at Highland Park
Replaced Model T with Model A

name: Gustave Eiffel
summary: Gustave Eiffel was a French civil engineer best known for designing the Eiffel Tower for the 1889 World's Fair in Paris. He also designed the internal structure of the Statue of Liberty and built bridges and viaducts across Europe. His pioneering work with iron and steel structures demonstrated that metal could create elegant, functional architecture.
timeline: Designed internal framework of Statue of Liberty
Eiffel Tower completed for World's Fair

name: George Westinghouse
summary: George Westinghouse was an American inventor and industrialist who championed alternating current (AC) power distribution, won the War of Currents against Edison's direct current system, and invented the railway air brake. He held 361 patents and founded the Westinghouse Electric Company, which powered the electrification of America.
timeline: Born in Central Bridge, New York
Won bid to light Chicago World's Fair with AC power
Installed AC generators at Niagara Falls
Forced out of companies during financial panic
